result.title: Objective
result.description: Working in an enabled environment sustainable management of the system of protected areas that have biodiversity, ecosystem and ecological process conservation as a major objective is ensured.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Development and Implementation of the system business plan

baseline.comment: No system business plan. Trust fund that includes proposal for retention scheme is under formation

target.comment: System business plan is developed and Different financing options including trust fund contribute to PA management

actual.comment: Business planning has never been exercised in any of the protected areas, despite the fact that EWCA has developed a business planning guideline. Government and donor funding are the sources of protected area activities. The trust fund, which would allow retention of income and diversifying the source is one major option, on which the development of a system business plan can be based on. A regulation to establish the trust fund has been finalized but has not yet been approved by the council of ministers.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Involvement and contribution of stakeholders including local community in PA management

baseline.comment: There is no formal involvement of stakeholders in PA management

target.comment: Model planning and monitoring of PA management with stakeholder participation is tested and replicated throughout all PAs.

actual.comment: As it has been discussed in the SDPASE's previous reports regarding involvement of communities and other stakeholders in PA management there have been informal co-management practices in some of them. Based on these experiences, it has now been declared by a regulation (by the council of ministers to designate boundaries of PAs article 5, ecnclosed) that all gazetted PAs should establish a committee composed of local government bodies, community members and other stakeholders which is charged with duties and responsibilities regarding PA management. Accordingly the project has planned to develop standard terms of agreement that will be signed between the PAs and the committee members.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Improvement in institutional capacity of Ethiopia's wildlife institutions

baseline.comment: EWCA's structure is not based on current state of the art of wildlife management

target.comment: EWCA is re-structured and re-oriented to current thought of wildlife management

actual.comment: The organizational re-structuring study conducted by a government based management institute that took almost a year is now on final stage. Draft proposal has been presented by the consultant two times to EWCA management and commented on. The company has now submitted the final version which is expected to be endorsed by July 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of endangered species [Walia, Swayne's Hartebeest , Elephant, Ethiopian Wolf, Grevy's zebra]

baseline.comment: Environmental conditions are deteriorating. Currently there are 300 Elephants in Babile, ,250 Ethiopian wolves in Bale, 1000 Walia in Simien , 750 Swayne's Hartebeest and 197 ± 54 Grevy zebra in Alledeghi

target.comment: Increase in Ethiopian wolf by 10% Elephants by 10% Grevy Zebra by 20%, Swayne's Hartebeest by 20% and Walia by 20% in these PAs

actual.comment:
The project has limited resources to conduct national wildlife surveys to proof percentage increases/decreases of the specified animals. However, as a result of increased awareness raising programs through media and in workshops as well as staff capacity building efforts and material support by the project only few incidents with regards to poaching of elephants and deaths of Ethiopian wolves through diseases have been reported during the year. However then following wildlife numbers have been reported by the experts of the respective PAs:
Ethiopian Wolf around 500
Elephant in Babile around 300
Grevy Zebra around 350
Swayne's Hartebeest around 850
Walia more than 1000 (no new figure

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Systemic capacity for protected area management consolidated

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of best practices consolidated for better PA management
Increase in METT score and Capacity Development Score Card

baseline.comment:
Best practices from APF and FZS on scouts training and management plan have been replicated
System METT score is 50%. Capacity Development Score Card not yet applied

target.comment:
4 Best practices (Community conservation, multi-stakeholder PA management, management planning, business planning) are consolidated and applied throughout the PA system
40% increase in system METT score. Capacity Development Score Card shows 15%increase over baseline (established in 2013)

actual.comment:
Multi stakeholder management is one of the best practices which has been tested in some protected areas though informally and based on willingness of the protected areas. This has now been declared by a regulation for seven protected areas which makes multi stakeholder management a must to implement.
Two community conservation areas have been established in Gambella and Afar Regional States and one more is under study in Ethiopia Somali Regional State with the support of the project. However, they have not yet become functional due to remoteness of the areas which leads to lack of interest by hunting companies and tourists which again leads to the communities being unable to generate any income. But with the current infrastructural development and increase in donors interest the community conservation areas will have a chance to be operational
There is definitely an increase in METT and Capacity Development Score Card scores with the current improvement in PA management. Compilation of the actual results is planned for April 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
1.1 Gaps in the legal framework for PA management bridged
Number of Proclamations and Regulations amended
Contradictions in framework made known

baseline.comment:
Existing proclamations and regulations
No write up on contradictions

target.comment:
3 Proclamations are amended and 11 regulations are issued and the issue of 8 regional regulations are supported
Contradictions are identified

actual.comment:
Seven federal regulations and eleven regional regulations to gazete protected areas have been issued. Two similar regulations and a regulation to establish a trust fund have been drafted.
Revision of two federal proclamations [Proc. No. 541/2007 and Proc. No. 575/2008] and one federal regulation [Regu. No 163/2008] has been finalized though not issued yet.
Seven utilization guidelines have been approved by the responsible minister.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
1.2 Planning system in place and harmonized
GMPs, Business Plans
Policy Paper PA-system
Management Planning Guidelines and system policy paper
Number of management plans developed and implemented

baseline.comment:
Guidelines and system strategic plan not available
2 GMPs are available and 3 are almost finalized [Awash, Babile and Gambella]

target.comment:
Guidelines and system strategic plan available
5 More GMPs are developed and 5 are implemented

actual.comment:
Management plan for Bale is under revision with the support of FZS for which SDPASE is providing expertise support. TOR to develop management plan for three PAs in 2016 have been drafted by the project
Five year strategic plan (2015 to 2019) for the wildlife sector of Ethiopia including regions has been developed with wider participation of relevant stakeholders with the support of SDPASE.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
1.3 Institutional implementation capacity both federal and regional strengthened
Increase in customer satisfaction
Number of partners and amount of co-finance secured for PA management
Improvement in EWCA's monitoring system

baseline.comment:
Customer satisfaction data are not collected
14 Organizations are working in PA management capacity building with USD 32 Million
Activity level monitoring

target.comment:
System for customer satisfaction data collection is emplaced
50% increase in customer satisfaction end of project
10% increase in number of co-financers and 25% increase in amount of co-finance
GEF/UNDP capacity building and METT score incorporated in EWCAâ€™s monitoring system

actual.comment:
In order to increase tourist satisfaction, during the reporting period the project has supported government efforts to improve tourist facilities, mainly road maintenance in Nechisar National Park and Senkelle Swayne's Hartebeest Sanctuary. In addition existing government owned lodges in Awash and Bale have been transferred to private investors. A training on tourism and tourist handling has been provided to tourism experts of EWCA.
The project has developed an improved monitoring guideline which has incorporated METT and other relevant monitoring tools in Amharic, official language of Ethiopia. Will be functional once EWCA has endorsed it.
Donors funding for wildlife management has increased by more than the target percentage (greater than 50% increase). The major donors are:
# A German based donor KFW 20 Million Euro for Simien, Bale and Alledghi
# Another German based donor GIZ 15 Million Euro for Nechisar, Awash and EWCA
# IGAD for Gambella NP management 6 Million Euro
# AWF for Simien NP 1.5 Million Dollar
# FZS in Bale, Guassa Menz, Simien 3.5 Million Euro

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
1.4 Gaps are prioritized and both federal and regional authorities are supported to create new PAs to fill the existing gap in the PA system
Number of new PAs created to fill the gap in the existing PA system

baseline.comment: Gaps in the existing PA system have been identified

target.comment:
Gaps are prioritized
Two new PAs are created in the identified gaps

actual.comment:
A wildlife potential area near to Gerale National Park has been identified and demarcated. A wildlife corridor has been established to connect it with former park to be administered under one management. Boundary of Alledeghi Wildlife Reserve (now proposed park) has been extended to include additional forest and wildlife potential areas.
Boundary of two wildlife potential areas of Benishangul Gumuz Regional State, Bejimiz and Maocomo, which were under study have been fully demarcated in this reporting period

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 1.5 Capacity of PAs staff developed for effective PA management Staff skills in the system

baseline.comment: Scouts' trainings, some professional level training and experience sharing are taking place

target.comment: The scouts training is conducted in EWCA's training institute, partnership is developed

actual.comment:
A partnership agreement has been reached on training of scouts with the military training academy in Awash Arba until EWCA is able to construct its own training center. A first round training has been provided to 80 scouts drawn from federal and regional PAs.
Training of trainers has been arranged for 11 senior scouts in the South Africa Wildlife College. They also had a chance to gain practical experiences from Kruger National Park. After returning back to Ethiopia, they have trained many scouts in their respective PAs and in the training program mentioned above.
Short term training on SMART, a software based wildlife management tool, has been provided to staff of three protected areas
The project has supported 12 postgraduate level EWCA staff students

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Sustainable financing mechanisms contributing to protected area budget

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Financial Sustainability Score Increase in investment in lodges

baseline.comment:
System Financial Sustainability Score to be established in 2013
Only three PA [Bale, Awash, Simien] have lodges.

target.comment:
10% increase in system Financial Sustainability Score
Additional 4 lodges are constructed in Bale, Simien, Gambella and Nechsar

actual.comment: Two new lodges are under construction in Simien Mountains National Park. New lodges in Senkelle, Nechisar and Abijata Shalla Lakes NP are under construction. One new lodge in Awash NP has become functional. The project has supported identification of areas which are ecologically sound for construction of lodges.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2.1 PA Trust fund is functional and received funding and start supporting PAs
Functional trust fund

baseline.comment: The trust fund is in starting stage

target.comment: Trust fund established and start financing PA management

actual.comment: The trust fund regulation has now been finalized. The project is lobbying for its approval by the responsible body.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
2.2 Business and marketing plans for system and PAs developed and implemented
Number PAs with Business Planning
Marketing strategy
Branding of PAs

baseline.comment:
Only one business plan for BMNP business planning guidelines available.
No marketing strategy
There is some informal branding

target.comment:
4 number of PAs use business planning
Marketing strategy developed and implementation started
All PAs are branded for promotion

actual.comment: EWCA is exercising branding of its protected areas using own experts. In the reporting period branding for two parks, Abijata Shalla Lakes and Awash, has been proposed though not approved yet. The project has planned to hire an external assistant to fasten the process and ensure quality.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
2.3 Income from PAs and wildlife increased [tourism, hunting, others, diversification of products]
Percentage increase in income
Number and type of promotion

baseline.comment:
ETB 42 Million ( in 2004 EC)
In 2011 Brochure 2 times, TV air time 10hrs, Bill board 1, T-shirts 5 type, poster 1 type, Magazine 1 times

target.comment:
15% increase in income
Doubling yearly production/sponsoring each type of promotion

actual.comment:
Income from wildlife tourism has increased by 42% from the baseline year. The folowing efforts have contributed to achieve this result.
The project has facilitated for journalists to attend all wildlife related events and give media coverage. More than 10 events such as world wildlife day, mountain trail in Abijata Shalla Lakes National Park, burning of ivory stockpile, a workshop to amend wildlife proclamation and regulations, areal survey in Gambella NP, higher government officials visit to PAs etc have been broadcasted through TV, Radio and news papers.
Signs have been erected in Nechisar and Awash National Parks.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
2.3 Income from PAs and wildlife increased [tourism, hunting, others, diversification of products]
Percentage increase in income
Number and type of promotion

baseline.comment:
ETB 42 Million ( in 2004 EC)
In 2011 Brochure 2 times, TV air time 10hrs, Bill board 1, T-shirts 5 type, poster 1 type, Magazine 1 times

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Replication of good practice models across protected area estate catalysed

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Revision and issuance of guidelines for different categories of PAs
Replication of the existing and new good practices gained from model and pilot sites
Number of PAs with multi-stakeholder coordination/consultation in management

baseline.comment:
There are guidelines for hunting
Good practices in management planning, business planning and scout training have been replicated
None of the PAs have such arrangements

target.comment:
One guideline is revised and 2 new guidelines are issued
The management planning and business planning are further replicated and other two good practices from pilot sites are replicated
5 PAs are being managed by multi-stake coordination/ consultation management

actual.comment:
Seven wildlife utilization guidelines have been revised and approved
Best practice in creating alternative livelihoods for communties living around the protected area to minimize unsustainable natural resource utilization from Simien Mountains National Park has been replicated to Nechisar and Senkelle. Community members who used to collect firewood for sale from these PAs have been supported to start bee keeping, poultry, sustainable fishing etc. as alternative means of living. 204 people (174 female) have benefited from these schemes.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
3.1 Capacity of PAs strengthened
Increase in management effectiveness of PAs

baseline.comment: METT score

target.comment: 30 % increase in Average METT

actual.comment: Compilation of METT scores have been postponed to 2016 due to time constraints. However positive changes are expected as a result of the increasing protected area support to enhance effectiveness of their management

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3.2 SDPASE project focal PA identified and their capacity built
Increase in management effectiveness in SDPASE focal PA [Alledeghi]

baseline.comment: Alledeghi METT score 48

target.comment: 40% increase in SDPASE-focal PA

actual.comment:
The project could not fully excert all of its effort on few protected areas because EWCA has given priority to system level support. But using its limited resources the project has managed to:
Construct a rain water harvesting structure in Senkelle for the wildlife, aimed at reducing the mortality rate of Swayne's Hartebeests because of lack of drinking water and killing incidents while crossing villages looking for water. These increases breeding capacity of the wildlife.
Construct an outpost in Alledeghi proposed national park to strengthen wildlife protection
Create an access for water supply in Abijata and Alledghi to reduce fuel and time spent to fetch water which could otherwise be used for park management
Create access to electricity for Babile and Alledeghi to enhance office work

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
3.3 Good practices from the whole system compiled and adapted to other PAs
Number of good practices compiled and tested

baseline.comment: Four model sites are selected but best practice only for one [Guassa Menz] has been compiled

target.comment: Good practice of the whole system compiled and tested in SDPASE focal PAs and disseminated to other PAs

actual.comment:
As discussed so far the project has not totally focused on few PAs. However with the support of the project best practices gained from some PAs have been applied on others. For instance
# The re-demarcation procedures used for Quafta Shiraro, Aliitash and Simien National Parks has been applied with some modification to re-demarcate Senkelle, Alledghi, Awash and Gerale. It has been found effective that we are also following the same procedure for the remaining un demarcated PAs
# Best practice from Simien mountains NP on creating environmental friendly livelihood schemes (only bee keeping is taken for time being) for the local community has been applied in Nechisar and Cheberachurchura NPs

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
3.4 Community conservation area guidelines applied to target areas [PFM, CHA, PA buffer zones]
Guidelines available and applied

baseline.comment: No guidelines

target.comment: Guidelines applied in 2 cases

actual.comment: The draft community conservation area management guideline could not be finalized due to lack of skill in the sector

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
2.3 Income from PAs and wildlife increased [tourism, hunting, others, diversification of products]
Percentage increase in income
Number and type of promotion

baseline.comment:
ETB 42 Million ( in 2004 EC)
In 2011 Brochure 2 times, TV air time 10hrs, Bill board 1, T-shirts 5 type, poster 1 type, Magazine 1 times

target.comment:
15% increase in income
Doubling yearly production/sponsoring each type of promotion

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Protected areas mainstreamed across all relevant sectors

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of sectors around PAs that incorporate wildlife component in their regular work plan
Number of community benefiting schemes and people benefitting from the schemes

baseline.comment:
No organization other than the wildlife sector has such component in its regular work plan
Three number of community benefiting schemes are available in Bale, Simien and GuassaMenz and 7000 people have generated about Birr 4 Million in 2004 ETC

target.comment:
The issue of PAs has become one component in regular plans of local govts., investors, NGOs, and sectoral bureaus around the 2 pilot sites
3 more PAs creates community benefiting schemes, for 3000 people , generating 2 Million Birr end of project

actual.comment:
Different sectors and local government bodies are giving due attention to protected areas as a result of awareness raising efforts exerted so far on values of protected areas.
In the reporting period new community benefit schemes have been created for people living around the protected areas. In Senkelle the local community has generated more than Birr 5 Million from selling of grass. More than 500 people have become beneficiary from biogas technology, beekeeping and other economic activities with the support of the project and the GEF small grant program.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
4.1 Successor plan of GTP (from 2015) contains strong references to protected areas in the framework of climate change, environmental services, gender and poverty reduction
Number and strength of Indicators in the next GTP
Increase in government budget

baseline.comment:
9 Indicators are incorporated in the current [2011-2015] GTP
USD 1.6 million including infrastructure

target.comment:
Number of indicators in next GTP remains the same but their strength increases
3 million

actual.comment:
Draft national GTP II has been developed with some indicators of wildlife but not yet approved
Lack of evidence-based budget requisition has been one of the reasons for EWCA not to get enough investment budget from government. This year infrastructural need assessment and total construction budget requirement has been developed for EWCA managed protected areas with the support of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
4.2 The value of PAs is studied and results are propagated
Compiled data on value of PAs

baseline.comment: A case study with old data

target.comment: Study on value of 5 PAs

actual.comment: Value of protected areas has been studied by a consultant. First draft report of the study has been commented on.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
4.3 PAs are mainstreamed in local level planning
Number of sectors with PA component in their plan

baseline.comment: No sector has such plan

target.comment: Three sectors in each focal area incorporate PAs in their plan

actual.comment:
Different sectors and local government bodies are giving due attention to protected areas as a result of awareness raising efforts exerted so far on value of protected areas. The following are some of the examples:
In Bale and Kafta Shiraro NPs local police and militia participate in patrolling and law enforcement.
A nearby local administration unit (Woreda) has supported construction of a road for Omo National Park
Wolaita Sodo University has supported Chebera Churchura National Park in creating alternative livelihood schemes to community members living around the park to reduce human pressure
Ethiopian road authority has constructed speed breaks on road that pass through Awash National Park
In the reporting period new community benefit schemes have been created for people living around the protected areas. In Senkelle the local community has generated more than Birr 5 Million/USD 250,000/ from selling of grass. More than 500 people have become beneficiary from biogas technology, beekeeping and other economic activities with the support of the project and GEF small grant program.
. Sectoral programs and organizaitons are increasingly contacting EWCA to obtain information on boundaries of PAs during their planning.

iati-activity.title: Mainstreaming Agrobiodiversity
iati-activity.description: The Global Environment Facility Mainstreaming Agro-biodiversity project objective is to mainstream the four selected crops (Coffee, enset, tef and durum wheat) in to the agricultural system of Ethiopia

result.title: Objective
result.description: To provide farming communities with incentives (policies, capacity, markets and knowledge) to mainstream conservation of agro-biodiversity, including crop wild relatives into the farming systems of Ethiopia

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 500ha established by end of the project

baseline.comment: In situ conservation happening in many isolated farms holdings, but no consolidated, deliberately set aside area being managed specifically to maintain wild relatives

target.comment: At least 300ha of on farm/in situ conservation sites established by project mid-term and 500ha established by end of the project

actual.comment: The coverage of the land for two cereal crops (tef and durum wheat) was very from season to season since the farmers are using crop rotation approach to reduce soil fertility loss, dissemination of disease, insect and so on. Accordingly, 1,186.7 and 66.3ha were covered by Tef and durum wheat respectively. The area coverage of Forest coffee alone covers 167,021ha. Therefore, the achievement of the project was more than 500ha of land covered by the on farm conservation of farmers varieties of the intended four crops.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 3 agro-biodiversity policies revised to mainstream agro-biodiversity conservation and institutional arrangement for their implementation strengthened

baseline.comment: Currently agro-biodiversity conservation is catered for in some policies and the IBC has the responsibility at national level for its conservation. There are policy contradictions and several key policies (trade, agriculture, forestry) still do not recognize agrobiodiversity. Institutional arrangement especially mandates at the Woreda and Kebele levels still unclear, and have weak capacities

target.comment: At least five policies evaluated for their effectiveness in agro-biodiversity conservation and recommendations for gap filling made by the end of the project; Institutional mandates for agroBD conservation clarified at all levels and Woreda and Kebbele governments in 4 pilot sites have capacity for mainstreaming agroBD conservation and governance to enforce policy and legislation provisions (on AgroBD conservation).

actual.comment: At its final execution period, the project has engaged in implementation of the policy evaluation recommendations. The policy evaluation articulated the existing policy gaps in the agrobiodiversity conservation and highlighted the need for the establishment of regional biodiversity conservation centers to closely support local communities instead of only the Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute working at the Federal level. Accordingly nine regional centers at Awassa, Metu, Goba, Shashemene, Fiche, Mekelle, Bahir Dar, Harar and Assossa are established and strengthened by the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Markets for agro-BD friendly products increased by at least 50% (through expansion of value chains and national and international markets for agro-biodiversity)

baseline.comment: Currently there is one international agreement on tef, less than 5% of coffee being sold as speciality coffee, very limited trade on durum wheat or enset.

target.comment: At least three value chains with clear national and international markets established by mid-project and five value chains established by end of project

actual.comment: During the reporting period, the project was strongly worked on strengthening of the market linkage created between five forest Coffee producing and marketing farmers associations in Yayu and Oromia Coffee exporting farmers union. This support given on the strengthening of market linkage to the farmer’s cooperatives reduced the middlemen and increased the benefit of the beneficiary communities. In 2014 the farmer’s cooperatives supplied 746qt of forest coffee to the International market through Oromia coffee exporting union. At Minjar-shenkora project site, two farmers associations supplied 650qt Tef for consumers’ cooperative found in Adama Town and 163qt for kesem union. Due to the effort of the project, the MoU between G7 sack factory and farmers associations has been renewed in 2014. According to the renwed MoU, Enset producing, conserving and marketing farmers’ association in Angacha supplied 400kg fiber of Enset and earn better income. This all efforts of the project practically increased the capital of the farmer's cooperative/ association and change the livelihood of the beneficiary communities at grassroots level.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Reduced or avoided deforestation and forest degradation and improved forest restoration through Payment of Ecosystem Services as conservation incentives

baseline.comment: Awareness of the potential for developing a PES project is very high in the country, and some effort is being put to identify specific areas and design projects aimed at the UNREDD initiative. However, no PES project has been submitted to the CDM yet

target.comment: At least one PES project (on carbon sequestration with a target of 27.4 M tCO2e ER) initiated through REDD by project mid-term and an integrated forest management/governance structure to ensure continued provision of ecosystem services in place by end of project

actual.comment: The project has aggressively engaged in awareness creation and reforestation efforts in Yayu site. Tthe project raised and distributed 648,433 indigenous forest tree seedlings to the communities which support the reforestation program. Furthermore the project has also initiated the PES study to implement the payment incentives for conservation of biodiversity resources.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enabling policy and institutional framework for in situ conservation of agro-biodiversity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Ministries of agriculture, forestry, trade and industry with policies catering agrobiodiversity conservation

baseline.comment: Currently Agro-biodiversity friendly policies are scattered and inadequate

target.comment: At least 3 Agro-biodiversity principles mainstreamed into local and national agricultural, trade and industry policies and programs

actual.comment: The project has supported to mainstream key agrobiodiversity principles into relevant government sectors such as Agriculture, Trade, Industry and Tourism by: (i) Increasing knowledge and understanding of agrobiodiversity as an essential resource for sustainable development and well-being. In this relation all the four project sites local governments have mainstreamed this principles in all relevant sector offices. (ii) The project has contributed for global significance and influences research and policy agendas on agrobiodiversity. For example, farmers’ varieties of Durum Wheat gene pool is attracted researchers for controlling wheat rust which is highly devastating the improved varieties of wheat both nationally and globally. Moreover, research on drought resistance and early maturing varieties is being done by the local researchers on Teff and Durum Wheat in collaboration with the project. (iii) The project has put its effort in mainstreaming the importance of wild species in agricultural landscapes, food sources and key ecosystem functions through the restoration and conservation of Teff, Durum Wheat and Yayu Forest Coffee (iv) One of the greatest achievements of the project is its ability to involve farmers and local communities, respects and strengthens their indigenous knowledge through the development and endorsement of four local bylaws. (v) The Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute is highly engaged in advocating the conservation of agrobiodiversity and access and benefit sharing at global fora in collaboration with the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Local institutions have farmer variety bylaws and regulations in 4 pilot areas

baseline.comment: There are currently no farmer variety policies in pilot areas

target.comment: At least 3 local government authorities assisted to develop capacity and accountability to enforce policies, sectoral guidelines and spatial plans in support of agro-biodiversity increased in 5 pilot areas by end of project

actual.comment: The project has developed the capacities of the Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute (EBI) and the Ethiopian Agriculture Institute of Research (EAIR) at the federal level. Moreover, capacities of four local governments at Gimbicu, Minjar Shenkora, Angacha and Yayu woredas have been developed. As a result EBI has supported the establishment of nine regional biodiversity centers. EAIR has engaged in participatory plant breeding on the four farmers’ varieties to improve productivity of Farmers Variety crops. All the four local governments have endorsed the local bylaws as official working documents. This project best practice is being replicated in the project implementation nearby woredas and kebeles.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Local institutions have farmer variety bylaws and regulations in 4 pilot areas

baseline.comment: There are currently no farmer variety policies in pilot areas

target.comment: At least 4 FV Policies applied in 4 pilot areas & adopted in 12 woredas / 36 kebeles supporting implementation

actual.comment: During the reporting period, five policies recommendations were implemented at national level and four project sites. This practice is being replicated in the nearby additional eight woredas and 63 kebeles. The achievement was by far more than planned. This is due to the local authorities and beneficiary communities are applauded the project achievements in respective cabinet meetings and different forums.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: National extension programme promote farmer varieties and land races

baseline.comment: The National extension service has a strong bias to promote HYVs at the expense of traditional farmer varieties

target.comment: At least 40% of the farmers in the 4 pilot areas provided with skills and knowledge to increase farm productivity (and food security) by 30% using agro-biodiversity friendly practices

actual.comment: In collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture (MoA) and Ethiopian Institute of Agricultural Research (EIAR), the project has been finalized the development of an extension package for four targeted crops (Durum Wheat, Tef, Enset and Forest Coffee). 400 copies (100 for each package) has been published and distributed to the project sites and relevant institutions. ToT training also given for 100 experts came from Zone, Woreda and kebel (Development Agents) level. By the coordination of each project site officers, the experts acquired the ToT training has providing continues practical trainings for all beneficiaries /farmers/ on the extension packages. This improved the skill and knowledge of the farmers and increase productivity of the crops as well as surly contributed to the efforts to the food security. Based on the interest of the local experts (development agents (DAs) who are technically supporting farmers at grass root level), the project is developing training manuals for the intended four crops in collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture. The training manuals will be smutted sooners and trainings will be given for the experts. This will be technically support the extension packages found under implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Local institutions have farmer variety bylaws and regulations in 4 pilot areas

baseline.comment: There are currently no farmer variety policies in pilot areas

target.comment: At least 60% of the CSOs in pilot areas have skills to actively support communities to integrate at least 4 FV into farming systems, and link such production to private sector markets

actual.comment: In order to climax the beneficiary communities’ interest in conserving the farmer’s varieties, the project has been bought 35qt of durum wheat and 30qt of tef seed and handover to the farmer’s cooperatives. So many awareness raising trainings also given to the beneficiary communities on the implementation of the local bylaws prepared on the Agro-biodiversity conservation and how to create links with the potential CBOs. The project also strengthens the affiliation with the relevant CBOs such as Ethio- Organic Seed Action and Environment and Coffee Forest Forum (both CBOs are member and active participant in the Steering Committee of the project) and Melka Ethiopia. Those CBOs leaders were showed an interest to support the cooperatives/associations after the project closure. This will have significant contribution in the sustainability of the project achievements.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Local institutions have farmer variety bylaws and regulations in 4 pilot areas

baseline.comment: There are currently no farmer variety policies in pilot areas

target.comment: At least 2 extension packages per target crop developed by mid-term and used to promote and integrate farmer varieties into the national extension service package and delivery system by end of project

actual.comment: A comprehensive four extension packages addressing productivity, protection, agronomic practices, etc of the four intended crops developed in collaboration with the Ethiopian Ministry of Agriculture (MoA) and Ethiopian Institute of Agriculture Research and utilized by the beneficiary communities. Additionally four training manuals have been developed as hands on tools for the local level extension experts. As these packages were developed in collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture, the packages are recognized as part of the National Extension Service System.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: An effective M&E for assessing conservation status of agro-biodiversity at community level

baseline.comment: Conservation status of FVs and CWR is weak and their contribution to local food security is not well documented

target.comment: Agriculture programs in the 4 project sites adopt a participatory M&E system for assessing the conservation status of FV and CWR by mid-term and the contribution of CWR and FV to local food security assessed by end of project

actual.comment: Needs were assessed to identify the capacity gaps of Farmers Cooperatives/ associations on M&E. Based on the capacity gaps identified, trainings were organized at four project sites for project staffs, woreda experts and leaders of farmers cooperatives/associations on monitoring and evaluation for 188 participants (72 females). The impacts of the capacity building activities offered so far also conducted at four sites and documented for future use. The impact assessment results of the four project site indicated that, the capacity building activities implemented so far were really addressing the capacity gaps of the beneficiary communities as well as the local Institution and also facilitate the mainstreaming of the agrobiodiversity conservation principles in to different sectors at all level in the selected project sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: A strengthened national institutional framework for agro-biodiversity

baseline.comment: A national institutional framework for agro-biodiversity conservation exists but it is dysfunctional

target.comment: A well articulated national institutional framework for agro-biodiversity conservation agreed upon by mid-term and implemented by end of project

actual.comment: As per the five sectors institutional frame work mandates analysis recommendations, currently a well-articulated national institutional framework has been developed and the Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute (EBI) has formulated from the then Institute of Biodiversity Conservation (IBC). Since the previous one was mainly focused on conservation while the current has made including researches and conservation.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Markets for agro-biodiversity friendly products promote farmer uptake of agro-biodiversity conservation imperatives

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: International and national demand for five agro-BD friendly products increased

baseline.comment: Though there is a demand for agro-biodiversity products such as honey, there are more opportunities that can be tapped to increase this demand

target.comment: At least 4 marketing programs identified, differentiated and certified for products from 4 pilot areas (e.g. shade, wild and low caffeine coffee, durum wheat, ensette, teff, noug) by mid-term and non certified agro-BD products grown in shade coffee farms and coffee forests developed and implemented through a supply chain approach by end of project

actual.comment: Four marketing strategies has been developed and implemented for the four crops. Accordingly four market linkages have been identified and implemented through supply chain. (i)Teff producers re linked to Kesem Uniun and Mama Fresh Enjera exporting company. (ii) Enset producers are linked to G7 Sack factory. (iii) Durum Wheat producers are being linked to Akaki Food processing Factory. (iv)Yayu Forest Coffee has been certified by Rain Forest Alliance and linked to Oromiya Coffee exporter. However, the project is supporting the Yayu Forest Coffee producers to form their own union for accessing international market directly.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Production, processing and marketing of agrobiodiversity friendly products improved in 4 pilot areas through the formation of cooperatives with strong organizational and operational capacities

baseline.comment: There are many local level producer societies but there are major gaps in capacity and in particular they are not differentiated by function (production, processing, marketing); they have very limited operational and organizational capacities and fail to link farmers to markets and credits adequately

target.comment: At least 50% of local level producer societies for specific crops (such as shade and low caffeine coffee, durum wheat, teff, ensette) in 4 sites promoted as a mechanism of incentives for adoption by linking farmers to markets and credit

actual.comment: The project providing support for 24 farmers associations/cooperatives at four project sites which accommodate 76,953 members of which 36,443 or 47% are females. Two metal silo grain storage with the capacity of 10qt for each also bought and handover to Gimbichu site farmers Cooperatives (one for each Cooperative). Intensive Capacity building trainings were offered to the beneficiary communities on cooperative management and auditing, natural resource conservation, operation of threshers and others. Three market sheds constructed at Gimbichu, Minjar-shenkora and Anagacha sites were handover to the beneficiary communities and functioning well.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Awareness of the importance of Agro-biodiversity-friendly products in promoting conservation and communitiesâ€™ welfare in Ethiopia raised at local, national and international level

baseline.comment: There is limited awareness on importance of Ethiopiaâ€™s agro biodiversity; and even more limited awareness of the role this agrobiodiversity plays in local economic development and food security; and limited awareness of the options and potential that exist to use specialized products to promote both local welfare, economies and conservation. Agro-biodiversity friendly products are available but they have not absorbed the available market share

target.comment: At least 10 international marketing campaigns (trade fairs, online) to establish Ethiopia as an international source of agro-BD friendly products held by mid-term and production of agro-biodiversity products to satisfy the markets increased by 50% by end of project

actual.comment: Different marketing companies have been done to promote the four intended crops to the world. Four billboards and light box (one for each crops) prepared and displayed at the Bole international Airport since 2014 up to 2016. Three national and international exhibitions and bazar (in Addis Ababa, Mekelle and Awassa) have been conducted and increased the visibility of the four crops nationally and globally. One international promotion has been also done at Doha during CoP18 in 2012. The project has also used different international celebrations such as the International Biodiversity day to communicate its achievements globally. Furthermore, documentary film was produced on the four crops and transmitted on the Ethiopian National Television. Additionally, two hours interview on importance and use of the four crops also done by the Bisrat FM radio and transmitted.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Business and financial capacity in place to produce agro-BD friendly products and services in 5 pilot sites

baseline.comment: There are limited credit opportunities for SMEs involved in agro-biodiversity friendly businesses

target.comment: At least 60% of micro and SM enterprises engaged in Agro-BD friendly businesses and services assisted to access credit through partnerships and capacity building of financial institutions by end of project

actual.comment: About 75% of the producers’ cooperatives/associations have access to credit services: Yayu forest coffee producers linked to Sorena Geba Union, Minjar-shenkora and Tef producer farmers’ cooperatives linked to Kesam union. The credit facilities has supported both associations to improve and increase their products.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Increased and stable income from certified and non-certified products grown in agro-BD friendly areas (shade coffee farms and coffee forest) in 4 pilot sites

baseline.comment: The current income levels from agro-biodiversity friendly products are far below the available market opportunities

target.comment: At least 2 different international crop certification systems established for shade coffee from coffee forest established by mid-term project and production increased by 50% while allowing 60% of the coffee farmerâ€™s in the site to sell products at a premium by end of project

actual.comment: Since the project is working on Yayu forest coffee, international certificate has been given by Rain Forest Alliance. As the result of the certification producers are able to supply their products to international market such as UK and Germany. Furthermore, branding for Minjar-shenkora farmer’s varieties of Tef is being finalized in collaboration with Debra Birhan University.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Verification and monitoring compliance of certification

baseline.comment: The available certification process needs to be monitored for compliance

target.comment: At least one protocol to verify and monitor compliance of certification developed by mid-project and used effectively by end of project

actual.comment: One Protocol to verify and monitor compliance of Yayu forest coffee certification has been made with Rain Forest Alliance during 2013. Yearly audit was performed and certified that the forest coffee producers were in line with the standards of Sustainable Agriculture Network (SAN).

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Crop Wild Relatives are conserved in in-situ gene banks (set side areas) that continue to provide â€œbreeding ground for agro-biodiversityâ€

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 500ha established by end of the project

baseline.comment: In situ conservation happening in many isolated farms holdings, but no consolidated, deliberately set aside area being managed specifically to maintain wild relatives

target.comment: The acreage of in-situ /on farm gene banks in 4 sites increased by 250,000 ha by mid-term and increased to 500,000 ha by end of project to ensure conservation of 4 crops and their wild relatives

actual.comment: The field gene bank found at Angacha project site was covered 2.08ha and 88 types of edible enset collected from the farmer’s backyard and 113 wild relative of enset were appropriately managed. Forest coffee gene bank also established at Yayu site on 2.6ha of land. The area coverage of Forest coffee alone is 167,021ha of land. Practically the coverage of annual crops varies from season to season. Tef covers 1,186.7ha and durum wheat also covers 66.3ha in last production season. However, since commence of the project, the size of the land covered by the farmer’s varieties shows an increasing trend. Therefore, due to referable efforts of the project so far, the coverage of in-situ/on-farm conservation of tef, durum wheat, enset and forest coffee increased remarkably.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 500ha established by end of the project

baseline.comment: In situ conservation happening in many isolated farms holdings, but no consolidated, deliberately set aside area being managed specifically to maintain wild relatives

target.comment: Capacities for sustainable management of the 4 conservation sites developed by mid-project and areas certified as sources of landraces and wild crop relatives by end of project

actual.comment: Continues capacity building trainings were offered to the beneficiary communities and local experts at four project sites on the conservation of farmer’s varieties of tef, durum wheat, enset and forest coffee. In Yayu project site, in collaboration with the woreda office of agriculture, gene pool inventory was conducted for the forest Coffee of the biosphere reserve. Similarly, through planting of additional Enset seedlings in Angacha Enset field gene bank, 2 additional new Enset varieties are identified and this will increase the number of Enset varieties in the field gene bank to 88. Two community gene banks construction activities are also ongoing with almost 95% accomplishment. The gene banks will be completed and handover to the beneficiary communities sooner.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 500ha established by end of the project

baseline.comment: In situ conservation happening in many isolated farms holdings, but no consolidated, deliberately set aside area being managed specifically to maintain wild relatives

target.comment: In situ gene banks management arrangements in 4 conservation sites agreed by mid-term and operational by end of project

actual.comment: During the reporting period two in situ gene banks established and managed at Yayu for Forest Coffee and at Angacha for Enset. Additional two community gen banks established at Gimbichu for Durum Wheat and at Minjar Shencora for Tef.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Effectiveness of institutions in management of in situ gene banks

baseline.comment: Degradation of in situ gene banks continue unabated since the national and regional institutions charged with the management of in situ gene banks lack effective management strategies

target.comment: At least 4 capacity building programs are developed and implemented by mid-term to ensure 50% of the institutions charged with responsibility for managing the in-situ gene banks in 4 sites are effective by end of project.

actual.comment: Assessment of the capacity gaps of the farmers’ association/cooperatives was conducted by consultant. Based on the consultant’s capacity need assessment results, trainings were organized on basic accounting, cooperative management, value chain development for 39 participants (35 male & 4 female), on operation of multipurpose thresher for 20 participants (2 female & 18 male). Materials (Enset processing tools, farm tools, office equipment, stationery, etc) were provided to the farmers’ cooperatives/associations found at four project sites. In collaboration with the Ethiopian Institute of Agriculture (EIAR) participatory plant breeding approaches also continuously supported by the project. Furthermore 20 accessions of durum wheat and 12 accession of tef has been retrieved from the Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute (EBI) gene bank and evaluated at the Framers Training Centers (FTC) continuously in order to come-up with the conclusion of the comparative advantage of the farmers varieties over the improved one. Farmers were actively participated on the evaluation of those accessions performance. Due to those supports rendered to farmers cooperatives/associations, the request for membership of the farmers’ cooperatives/associations highly increasing from time to time. This is one of the practical changes observed due to the well-organized intervention project at four woredas.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 500ha established by end of the project

baseline.comment: In situ conservation happening in many isolated farms holdings, but no consolidated, deliberately set aside area being managed specifically to maintain wild relatives

target.comment: At least one Project Design Document (PDD) carbon sequestration target of 27.4 M tCO2e ER as a result of better management and protection of the coffee forest completed and placed on the voluntary carbon market by mid-term and initial financial benefits accrued by end of project

actual.comment: Strategic Guideline in Integrated Natural Resources Management to increase adaptive capacity of Farmers Varieties to Climate change in Enset, Forest coffee, Tef and Durum wheat growing Woredas was developed in collaboration with the MoA, Natural Resources Mnagement Directorate, CRGE unit. Validation workshop and training also conducted in presence of relevant stakeholders. Currently 200 copies of the document was published and distributed to the project site and other stockholders. The English version of the document has been translated to local languages (Amharic and Afan Oromo) and distrusted to the implementers in hard and soft copies. Furthermore the project has also initiated the PES study to implement the payment incentives for conservation of biodiversity resources.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To support local communities and administrations at the lowest level of government to design and implement adaptation actions aimed at reducing vulnerability and building resilience, especially in those communities that are particularly vulnerable in Ethiopia

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Capacity perception index, disaggregated by Gender

baseline.comment: Average CCA capacity scorecard rating of 1.26 across men and women

target.comment: CCA capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 3 in target Woredas for both men and women

actual.comment: Since the inception of the project implementation, the project has been providing different capacity building trainings to enhance institutional capacity at lowest administrative levels, mainly at the 4 Woredas and the 8 Kebeles ( Mesebo &Mesret kebeles in Enderta woreda,) (Selga 23 & Kushmengel kebeles Asossa woreda), ( Desta Abijata &Kemo Gerbi kebeles in Adami Tulu Jido Kombolcha woreda) and (Pukong&Pimoli kebeles in Gambela Woreda ), on how to engage in multi-stakeholder dialogue; assess situation; create a mandate and vision; formulate policy and strategy; budget management and implementation as well as monitoring and evaluation. Based on this support, task team members have been able to design and provide mentoring support to beneficiary community members at the Kebele level in integrating and implementing new CC adaptation techniques and technologies. Furthermore, beneficiary farmers have gained practical knowledge on participatory planning methods. In so doing, capacity in properly designing and implementing CC adaptation measures that would reduce vulnerability and build the resilience of local communities to climate change in the PAA pilot Kebeles and in Addis Ababa has improved. In general, the institutional capacity is improved for a total of 333 (88 F&245 M) woreda task team members,DA agents & Woreda task teams, from the baseline 1.26 to 2.85 score.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Adaptation actions implemented in national/sub-national development frameworks

baseline.comment: Limited mainstreaming of adaptation into national food security and land management programmes

target.comment: By the end of the project at least two national programmes have mainstreamed climate change adaptation in to their based on lessons learned from this LDCF project

actual.comment: In order to help a national level mainstreaming of climate change adaptation,the project has started documenting the best practices that would be lessons to be shared to sub-national and national levels which can positively influence decision makers to mainstream CC adaptation into national food security and land management programmes

baseline.comment: Limited mainstreaming of adaptation into sub-national planning processes and policies

target.comment: By the end of the project at least four Woreda and one Regional development plan have been revised to incorporate climate change risks and opportunities

actual.comment: Based on the four Woredas CC adaptation plans, all Woredas have revised their development plan. These plans are now part of the Woreda Development Plans in which CC issues are incorporated. Following the plan revision, all woredas have started transforming to implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Increase in climate resilient agricultural production in the target areas

baseline.comment: Currently, only ad hoc adoption of adaptation measures by subsistence farmers, and agriculture is climate vulnerable.

target.comment: By the end of the project, 5000 subsistence farmers have adopted adaptation measures and climate resilient agricultural production has increased by 12.5% in target areas compared to baseline (1t/ha maize) and for adjusted for rainfall.

actual.comment: In order to improve farmers' access to technologies and practices that have CC adaptation value the project provided material and technical as well as training support to a total of 4479 (2547 male which is 51% of the target and 1932 female which is 39% of the target) farmers and they have been implementing, different CC adaptation technologies such as climate resilient agricultural crop and vegetable production through small scale irrigation using rain water harvesting techniques, shallow well drilling and application of solar pumps and by applying drip irrigation techniques, river diversion techniques, on a total of 1,200 hectares of land across all sites. On so doing they have been able to harvest more production. in general, the average growth of productivity in all production items is estimated to grow by 300% from the baseline production level across all pilot sites. This shows that there has been an increased production by 287.5% when compared to the expected target set at the end of the project period

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Institutional capacities for coordinated climate-resilient planning and investment strengthened.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimise exposure to climate vulnerability
Capacity perception index ,disaggregated by gender.

target.comment:
By end of Project, 4 Woreda and 1 Regional task teams have been trained in and use climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach,
Average CCA capacity score in the 4 Woreda and 1 Regional level is 3 for both men and women.

actual.comment: As follow-up practice from year 2014, the project continued providing training and mentoring support to all the 4 pilot rural Woredas and the 8 Kebele pilot sites as well as in Addis Ababa city government. Accordingly, in this reporting period, training and mentoring support was provided to 264 (79 F & 185 M) Woreda level task team members including planning experts, local level government representatives and local community members. The trainings have focused on how to: - Engage in multi-stakeholder dialogue; - Assess a situation and create a vision and mandate; - Formulate implementation policy and strategy; - Budget, manage and implement the planned intervention; and - Monitor and evaluate progress and feed back into the implementation management. After the trainings, those who participated in the trainings have used the knowledge to undertake climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach in their respective Woredas - the Woreda Task teams used the skills and knowledge they acquired from the training and undertook climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach in their respective Woredas. Apart from training support, "Simple pictorial-based information sheets on climate change, its causes and effects" designed for local community consumption was prepared and have been distributed to local level decision makers, planners and extension agents, in order to facilitate easy access to climate change related information. Capacity building support was also provided to 54 (8 F & 46 Male) in the 4 rural Woreda and to 15 (1 F & 14 M) task team members in Addis Ababa project task team members, to prepare area-based climate vulnerability profiles and climate risk analyses using GIS tools as part of the learning by doing approach for the development of the integrated plans. After the training, task team members have been able to undertake vulnerability assessment and produce local level vulnerability maps and documents for their respective localities. All in all, it could be said that the institutional capacity score has increased from the baseline score of 1.26 to 2.85.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Adaptation actions implemented in national/sub-national development frameworks

baseline.comment: Institutional capacity for cross-sectoral climate change planning is negligible

target.comment: Climate resilient investment strategies based on integrated climate resilient development plans are in place and attracting funding for 4 Woreda & 1 Regional area.

actual.comment: One of the main deliverable expected by the PAA project is the Addis Ababa green growth investment plan document which is going to be used for sharing lessons for other major cities in the Country. In this regard, in this reporting period, a consolidated Climate Resilient Green Growth investment plan for Addis Ababa is under preparation by a national consultant. The first draft was completed and it has been subjected to a peer-review by wider group of experts first. Currently, the consultant is incorporating the comments received from the review meeting. What remains is organizing a national stakeholders validation workshop to produce the final document.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Access to technologies and practices that improve the range and efficiency of adaptation options improved.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % of farmers adopting adaptation technologies, by technology type, disaggregated by gender.

baseline.comment: Farmers (83% male-headed, 17% female-headed) currently constrained by limited access to and knowledge of adaptation techniques and practices.

target.comment: By the end of the project, 5000 subsistence farmers (83% male-headed, 17% female-headed) have been trained in and tested climate change resilience building techniques and practices, of which 35% of both male and female headed farming households have adopted them permanently.

actual.comment:
In order to improve farmers' access to technologies and practices that have adaptation value, the project has provided material inputs as well as technical backstopping for beneficiary farmers and for communal actions undertaken for the purpose of environmental rehabilitation of forests or pasturelands, catchment management. Thus, in this reporting period in all project sites:
- Climate resilient conservation agriculture and crop diversification practices with the use of drought resistant crop varieties implemented; Small scale irrigation to grow market demanding fruits and vegetable crops through using rainwater harvesting technologies, low cost drip irrigation systems, human powered semi rotary water pumps and small to medium sized solar generated water pumps were implemented ; - improved bee keeping technologies and practices for honey and wax production that could improve the productivity and quality of the produce were supported by provision of modern beehives and accessories; - livestock production mainly goat and sheep production and fattening programme were implemented; - Development and use of household biogas energy and also production and use of energy efficient stoves were undertaken; - Environmental and natural resources management through area closure, construction of physical soil conservation measures, forest tree planting, and other similar practices were undertaken.
In order to enable farmers and woreda and kebele officials test the prioritized adaptation measures and technologies, practical trainings were provided and an experience sharing field demonstrations were organized by the project to a total of 832 (399 F & 433 M) farmers, 40 Developments Agents (DAs) and 44 woreda Task Team members The trainings focused mainly on different CC adaptation technologies including: Climate resilient agricultural crop and vegetable production practices; Modern and environmentally friendly animal husbandry mainly goat and sheep husbandry and fattening practices; modern apicultural practices including small scale irrigation using rain water harvesting techniques, shallow well drilling and application of solar pumps and by applying drip irrigation techniques; river diversion techniques; rehabilitation of degraded ecosystems; production and use of energy efficient stoves; and use of house holds level biogas energy production and use. Following the trainings, a total of 4479 (2547 male which is 50.94 of the target and 1932 female which is 38.64 of the target) farmers have been implementing above mentioned CC adaptation technologies and actions on their farm plots as an integrated set of adaptation actions on a total of 1,200 hectares of land across all sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Strengthened capacity of extension agents to transfer appropriate adaptation technologies by capacity score

baseline.comment: Currently there is only anecdotal evidence of capacity to transfer adaptation technologies score average 1.4

target.comment: By the end of the project 5 project task teams from 4 Woreda and 1 Regional administration have the capacity to transfer adaptation technologies with capacity score of 3

actual.comment: In this reporting period, the additional trainings, experience sharing visits organized by the project, and the overall exposure to CC adaptation technologies have contributed highly to all extension agents and all the l woreda and Addis Ababa task teams in terms of enhancing their capacity to first understand, identify, select, and transfer adaptation technologies. Accordingly, the project task teams and extension agents from the 4 Woreda and Addis Ababa City Government have been involved actively in properly transferring adaptation technologies to beneficiary farmers. Hence I would say that the capacity of all task team members across all Woredas to transfer adaptation from has improved from the baseline score 1.26 to 2.85.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Capacity for community-based climate change adaptation improved.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % of targeted population covered by innovative insurance mechanisms, disaggregated by gender.

baseline.comment: Informal coping strategies are in use in target areas, no formal financial risk reducing/insurance approaches yet in place due to lack of meteorological and hazard information in target areas

target.comment: By the end of the project at least 25% of the men and 25% of the women in the target communities are using innovative mechanisms to insure against the inherent uncertainty of climate change

actual.comment: In order to facilitate the access to climate information, which is considered as a constraining factor in reducing vulnerability to the perceived seasonal unpredictability of weather in all the PAA project sites including in Addis Ababa, different activities have been performed in this reporting period. Support was provided to the National Meteorological Agency (NMA) to present its available downscaled weather forecast information, which could be used for seasonal projections and/or longer term climate related projections for risk planning, to target Woreda level planners and beneficiary farmers in a way that they can find it useful and gather feedback in a way that improves their own forecasting. In order to create awareness and sufficient understanding to Woreda planners, DAs and Kebele level officials on downscaled weather data and on how to interpret this data to climate information and adjust their interventions and disaster risk management plans, different training sessions were organized by the project to a total of 1128 (487F & 641M) participants from across the project sites. Due to the these trainings, Woreda and local level awareness about the issue has increased substantially and about 38.96 female and 51.28 male target beneficiary communities have started using climate data effectively in their decision making processes. Thus, in general, the average growth of productivity in all production items is estimated to grow by 300% from the baseline production level across all pilot sites. This shows that there has been an increased production by 287.5% than when compared to the expected target set at the end of the project period. Due to this increase in productivity beneficiary farmers' income has increased and substantially supported their livelihood.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in climate resilient agricultural productivity in the target areas

baseline.comment: Very limited capacity for applying climate resilient agriculture

target.comment: By the end of the project, climate resilient agricultural production has increased by 12.5% in target areas compared to baseline (1t/ha maize) and for adjusted for rainfall.

actual.comment: In this reporting period, through the project support, 8 Automatic Weather Stations in all the 8 PAA project Kebele sites were installed. Accordingly, collection of real time weather information was made possible using these Automatic Weather Stations (AWSs). The data from the AWSs were directly transmitted to NMA server and the processed information from NMA is sent back to the 8 Kebeles through Woreda offices. Thus, currently Woreda level planners, DAs and farmers have been able to access realistic and up-to-date short term (seasonal) weather projection data. Using the information provided, beneficiary farmers have been able to make proper decision on their agricultural practices and have been able to get an increased production from their farm plots. Thus, the average growth of productivity in all production items is estimated to grow by 300% from the baseline production level across all pilot sites. This shows that there has been an increased production by 287.5% than when compared to the expected target set at the end of the project period. Furthermore, in order to insure community members against inherent climate change induced uncertainties the project has supported the design of weather index insurance mechanisms for each of the pilot kebeles and started covering the crop insurance premiums for 1840 interested beneficiary farmers in the pilot Kebeles to test and refine the design of the scheme farmers who are interested in the insurance mechanism.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Ethiopia.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard.
2. Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change.

baseline.comment:
1. Limited capacity to generate EWS and CI on a national scale for extreme hydro-meteorological phenomena. There are no Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for alert communication by NMA to DRMFSS.
Current score: 83.
2. Existing budget plans do not have sufficient funds to maintain and operate the environmental monitoring infrastructure.
Current budget: low.

target.comment:
1. Capacity assessment scorecard score of 139.
2. Domestic target financing is 100M Birr per year.

actual.comment:
40 AWS have been procured. One upper air radio sonde equipment has also been procured and is ready for installation. A meteorological mobile calibration unit and equipment have been procured and they are already functional. Automatic hydrological gauge telemetry equipment has been identified and is ready to procure.
Capacity building training sessions for instrument technicians, forecasters and support staffs as well as awareness-creation events for local communities have been held in various parts of the country, particularly for all NMA meteorological Branch Directorates staff and meteorological observers.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced capacity of NMA and HWQD to monitor extreme weather and climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Percentage of national coverage of the weather/climate and hydrological monitoring infrastructure.
2. Frequency and timeliness of climate-related data availability.

baseline.comment:
1. Percentage of national coverage of the weather/climate and hydrological monitoring network at the beginning of the project:
Meteorological stations: 1,000 manual, 70 automatic;
Hydrological stations: 489 manual, 4 with telemetry.
2. Frequency of data transmission and collection: monthly.

target.comment:
1. Increase in 24% national coverage to take steps in achieving NMAs optimal monitoring arrangements as defined in feasibility studies:
Meteorological stations: 1240 manual stations, 110 automatic;
Hydrological stations: 439 manual, 64 with telemetry.
2. Frequency of data transmission and collection: daily.

actual.comment: With the exception of spare parts required to rehabilitate 200 conventional stations, most of meteorological equipment was ready for installation. However, the installation of the equipment and instruments was delayed as a result of difficulties to undertake civil works during the rainy season.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Efficient and effective use of hydro-meteorological and environmental information for early warnings and long-term development plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Percentage of population with access to improved climate information and flood and drought warnings (disaggregated by gender).
2. Development frameworks (e.g. GTP) that integrate climate information in their formulation.
3. Sector-specific EW products and strategies that integrate climate risks.

baseline.comment:
1. Use of hydro-meteorological and environmental information for making early warnings is currently low for both women and men.
Women: 6 million;
Men: 8 million.
2. Currently no development frameworks incorporate climate change information.
3. Limited number of tailor-made and sector-specific meteorological products. Limited public-private partnerships and pay for services contracts.

target.comment:
1. Percentage increase in the population who has access to improved EWS/CI (50% increase for women and 50% increase for men).
Women: 9 million;
Men: 12 million.
2. At least 2 of the PRSP policy briefs incorporate analyses of risk maps and/or climate change projections influencing long-term planning proposals.
3. Development of at least one tailored climate product and presentation of a market research plan on how to implement mobile phone based agricultural advisories, both supporting targeted weather/climate service delivery.

actual.comment: This part of the project will be executed after all the equipment is installed and capacity building sessions are held for experts and at the community level. The execution of activities is planned to start in 2016.
